title: 2010–11 Ekstraklasa
text:
The 2010–11 <a href="Ekstraklasa">Ekstraklasa</a> was the 77th season of the highest level of <a href="Association%20football">football</a> leagues in <a href="Poland">Poland</a> since its establishment in 1927. It began on 6 August 2010 and concluded on 29 May 2011. A total of 16 teams participated, 14 of which competed in the league during the 2009–10 season, while the remaining two were promoted from the <a href="I%20Liga%20%28Poland%29">I Liga</a>. Each team played a total of 30 matches, half at home and half away.
<a href="Wis%C5%82a%20Krak%C3%B3w">Wisła Kraków</a> won the title, which marked their 13th title in total.
<a href="Wis%C5%82a%20Krak%C3%B3w">Wisła Kraków</a> qualified as champions for the 2nd qualifying round of the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2011–12 UEFA Champions League</a>, while <a href="%C5%9Al%C4%85sk%20Wroc%C5%82aw">Śląsk Wrocław</a>, as the runner-up, entered the 2nd qualifying round of the <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2011–12 UEFA Europa League</a>, followed by the fourth placed <a href="Jagiellonia%20Bia%C5%82ystok">Jagiellonia Białystok</a> team that earned a place in the 1st qualifying round of the Europa League. <a href="Legia%20Warsaw">Legia Warsaw</a>, the winner of the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Polish%20Cup">2010–11 Polish Cup</a>, also earned a place in European competition by qualifying to the 3rd qualifying round of the Europa League.
The defending champions were <a href="Lech%20Pozna%C5%84">Lech Poznań</a>, who won their sixth Polish championship <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Ekstraklasa">last season</a>.
Teams.
Promotion and relegation was established by a change, which eliminated relegation play-off games after the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Ekstraklasa">2008–09</a> season. Thus, the 14th team from the Ekstraklasa and the 3rd team from the Polish First League no longer competed against each other in play-offs. Following the change, promotion and relegation were determined solely by a team's position in the table. As usual, the bottom two teams were directly relegated to the <a href="I%20Liga%20%28Poland%29">I Liga</a>, while the top two teams were promoted to the Ekstraklasa.
<a href="Odra%20Wodzis%C5%82aw">Odra Wodzisław</a> and <a href="Piast%20Gliwice">Piast Gliwice</a> finished in 15th and 16th place, respectively, and were directly relegated to the Polish First League as a result. <a href="Odra%20Wodzis%C5%82aw">Odra Wodzisław</a> returned to the second tier after spending 14 years in the top division, their first appearance being in the <a href="1996%E2%80%9397%20Ekstraklasa">1996–97</a> season. Piast Gliwice spent just two seasons in the <a href="Ekstraklasa">Ekstraklasa</a>, after being promoted for the first time for the 2008–09 season, having spent the previous 71 seasons in the lower leagues.
Promotion was won by <a href="2009%E2%80%9310%20Polish%20First%20League">2009–10 2nd level</a> champions <a href="Widzew%20%C5%81%C3%B3d%C5%BA">Widzew Łódź</a>, who returned to the top division after being relegated in the <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20Ekstraklasa">2007–08</a> season. 14-time Ekstraklasa champions <a href="G%C3%B3rnik%20Zabrze">Górnik Zabrze</a> finished as runners-up in the I Liga and made their comeback to the top tier after being relegated in the 2008–09 season.
Stadiums and locations.
Since and prior to the selection of Poland as co-host for <a href="2012%20UEFA%20Euro">Euro 2012</a>, numerous clubs were engaged in reconstruction of their stadiums, or building a completely new stadium. Some teams in the beginning of the season played their home matches in other stadiums. For instance <a href="Wis%C5%82a%20Krak%C3%B3w">Wisła Kraków</a> played their home matches at the <a href="Hutnik%20Krak%C3%B3w">Hutnik Kraków</a> stadium, the <a href="Stadion%20Suche%20Stawy">Stadion Suche Stawy</a>, which held 12,000 spectators. However, the move to the nearly completed 33,000-plus home stadium was in effect mid-season. <a href="Legia%20Warsaw">Legia Warsaw</a> and <a href="Lech%20Pozna%C5%84">Lech Poznań</a> played at stadiums which remained under construction but nearing completion. <a href="Dialog%20Arena">Dialog Arena</a>, the home venue of <a href="Zag%C5%82%C4%99bie%20Lubin">Zagłębie Lubin</a> was the newest completely finished stadium in the Ekstraklasa these season, being completed just before the start of the season.
<a href="Arka%20Gdynia">Arka Gdynia</a>, and <a href="Cracovia%20%28football%20club%29">Cracovia</a> started the season playing in their old stadiums. The two clubs moved to their completely finished new stadiums mid season. <a href="Jagiellonia%20Bia%C5%82ystok">Jagiellonia Białystok</a>, <a href="Lechia%20Gda%C5%84sk">Lechia Gdańsk</a>, and <a href="%C5%9Al%C4%85sk%20Wroc%C5%82aw">Śląsk Wrocław</a> played in their old stadiums while their new venues were being constructed. The 40,000 plus <a href="PGE%20Arena%20Gda%C5%84sk">PGE Arena Gdańsk</a> became the new home ground for Lechia after its completion in 2011, while Śląsk moved to the new 45,000 plus <a href="Stadion%20Miejski%20%28Wroc%C5%82aw%29">Stadion Wrocław</a>. The two stadiums were venues for Euro 2012.
Sponsoring and personnel.
<a href="Puma%20AG">Puma</a> continues as Ekstraklasa's official match ball suppliers through the 2010–11 season. All matches are played with the PUMA PowerCat 1.10 ultra balls, which is a special model created just for the Ekstraklasa.
The official presentation of the new ball for Ekstraklasa was prepared together with PUMA Poland in the beginning of August 2010 – just before the start of season. The case of prolonging the use of the match ball for the next two seasons was made official on 3 August 2010. The new model will be used through the 2011–12 season as it is regarded at the highest quality .
